job_title: Adjunct Professor, Graphic Design in Annapolis, MD
pros: Friendly. Flexible. Appreciated. Good communicators.
cons: Generally I think adjuncts are paid abysmally low, but AACC pays better than a lot of other places.

pros: great place to work as a student

pros: Good salary & benefits; Nice working environment

job_title: Associate Vice President in Millersville, MD
pros: Progressive Leadership. Outstanding faculty and focus on student success.
cons: Areas of opportunity exist with diversifying the workforce.

pros: Smooth hiring process, all the materials provided to teach the course.
cons: Everything was as expected - would reccomend.

pros: This is regular job with nice staff.
cons: There are no cons with this job.

pros: Teaching content that is interesting.
cons: There's no doubt AACC depends on its adjunct faculty to keep its ratings and respectability, yet they refuse to pay their teachers a living wage. There are no benefits for this job. Expect to do a great deal of lesson planning and grading, all of which will not be compensated. Expect to counsel students who may be the first in their family to go to college or facing an uphill battle with family or work issues but receive nothing for your assistance. Consider yourself a saint or volunteer. The stipend you will receive will be barely enough to cover grocery bills, so be prepared to work the maximum credits you can get on this campus if they will give it to you or don't take it away at the last minute, as well as several other campuses, or have a second job, pension, or spouse to depend on. It seems criminal to me that a campus that touts itself as one of the best community colleges in the nation could be so far behind other states and counties in their progress to improve the working conditions of the adjunct faculty. The administration continues to hire assistant deans at $100,000 apiece, improve their infrastructure, get advanced technology for certain departments, and help make education free or reduced for incoming students and it is all done on the backs of their adjunct faculty.

pros: It's a pretty campus, good library. They'll hire anyone, including an old private school teacher I know who broke a kids arm.
cons:
The college regularly breaks the Americans with Disabilities Act and other Civil Rights laws regarding disabled students. Professors are just expected to go along with it. The testing center has threatened a disabled student, and retaliated against disabled students who complain.

And some of the faculty are really weird and creepy. One department head essentially ran her own tutoring service on the side. A math adjunct liked to meet with students after hours in the math dept for 'tutoring,' during which he'd sit really close to the girls and rub up against them. I think some of the day classes are ok, particularly if you're not disabled, but some of the night-time adjuncts need medication. I remember one adjunct defending slavery to an African American student because, "at least it means you got to grow up in America."

Oh, and while I was there, senior management suggested I use extra-harsh grading to drive a problem student out of my class.

pros:
Nice Campus
Friendly Students
Treats Full Time Salaried Administration very well.
cons:
Non-salaried employees have many unpaid mandatory days off: snow days, spring break, winter break, and whenever salaried administration wants a paid day off.

Huge class disparity between salaried and hourly employees. Salaried administration treats hourly and 'temporary' staff like subhuman servants.

"Temporary" staff is never made full time and rarely given raises.  No raise for 3 years. Not even a dime. Temporary staff also frequently given Full Time staff duties without compensation.

Enforces a 30 hour a week limit in order to not pay benefits to hourly workers. Keeps them part time. Understandable, but often arbitrarily limits hours to 25 per week in order to not even get 'close' to risking health care options or overages.

pros: I've been an adjunct for many years. Great professional development opportunities. The students are fabulous.
cons: Lots of hot air blown about how important adjuncts and faculty are, but the reality is that the administration only cares about the administration. Faculty have little power and adjunct have even less. You can have excellent student evaluations, provide years of volunteer service on committees and then not even be given the opportunity to interview when a FT position does come open.

review_title: Expected so much more out of an institution for Higher Education
job_title: Network Administrative Specialist in Arnold, MD
pros: The benefits are out of this world, you only work 2/3 of the year, anytime college is closed you sit at home and get paid
cons: No room for advancement, pay, bureaucracy, if you have worked there for 12 years or more you make fantastic money, that was prior to the pay being regulated, at one point individuals were getting pay increases multiple times a year, took 5 years to get one pay increase

pros: Works around your schedule, friendly and helpful supervisors in the tutoring department, offers tutoring certification, salary goes up with your level of education and certification
cons: facilities are a bit lacking, a fridge in the tutoring lab would be nice, food on campus is expensive

pros: No pros at this place, I would rate an absolute 0 of it were an option with the exception of the benefits. Just horrible!
cons: Everything, everyone is out for themselves. If they have the opportunity to throw you under a bus they will, they then act like everything is okay.

pros: Nice work space and people, dedicated to doing a quality job each day.
cons: Mired in older technology and resistance to adopt new technologies and take a more global perspective.

pros: Everything, the staff with in CADE, was and will continue to be the most supportive, grateful, and inspirational. I was thanked for coming in each day and my work did not go unnoticed. The Director of the Gallery - Lindsay McCulloch was to the day the best boss I could ever ask for
cons: Having to be a full time student to work as a Gallery Assistant

job_title: Web Developer II in Arnold, MD
pros: Educational benefits, not-for-profit, feeling like what you do is for a cause nobler than someone's bottom line.
cons: Attitudes of some in management, lack of innovation or innovative ideas, a sometimes glacial pace for getting things done, politics.

pros: Good coworkers. Many of the intro courses, that adjuncts teach, are all packaged and ready to go, but there is still flexibility to customize the course.
cons: There is not as much direction as I would have thought for a first time adjunct. But you learn as you go.

pros: Over all satisfaction with the environment and the work has been friendly, positive,  outgoing.  The college provides a great learning atmosphere with a lot of talent, but I would like to have more work so taht I may qualify for benefits.

parttime 
no benefits for adjunct professors

review_title: Great place to work but lower pay than average

job_title: Student Services Assistant II in Hanover, MD

cons: Management needs to be more courteous to the students. Some employees hate dealing with the students. They obviously don't understand that is their job. Some Of upper management make fun of the students. The pay is not even worth applying for a job at this college.
